posts.text:
"We have two ears and one mouth, so we should listen more than we say."

— Zeno of Citium

"Man conquers the world by conquering himself."

Zeno founded Stoicism in Athens around 300 BC. His school met at the Stoa Poikile — the painted porch that gave the philosophy its name.

What does it mean to live well?

Zeno's answer: "The individual life is good when it is in harmony with nature."

days.imagePrompt: A muscular ancient figure in simple robes, gazing at a stormy sky with lightning representing Zeus, surrounded by elements of fate like threads or a wheel, in a dramatic classical engraving aesthetic, 4k

posts.text:
"He needs little who desires but little."

— Cleanthes

"Lead me, O Zeus, and thou, O Destiny."

Cleanthes succeeded Zeno as head of the Stoic school. A former boxer, he worked as a water-carrier by night to study philosophy by day.

Resistance or acceptance?

Cleanthes offered this: "The Fates lead the willing, but drag the unwilling."

days.imagePrompt: A scholarly ancient Greek man at a desk piled with scrolls, deep in thought with geometric logic symbols floating around him, illustrated in a timeless woodcut print style, 4k

posts.text:
"If I had followed the multitude, I should not have studied philosophy."

— Chrysippus

"Wise people are in want of nothing, and yet need many things."

Chrysippus wrote over 700 works on logic, ethics, and physics. He systematized Stoic thought so thoroughly that later thinkers said: "Without Chrysippus, there would be no Stoa."

How should we live?

Chrysippus: "Living virtuously is equal to living in accordance with one's experience of the actual course of nature."

days.imagePrompt: A wise Roman philosopher in modest attire, sharing a simple meal outdoors with students, evoking everyday virtue and restraint, in a soft watercolor book illustration, 4k

posts.text:
"You will earn the respect of all if you begin by earning the respect of yourself."

— Musonius Rufus

"If you accomplish something good with hard work, the labor passes quickly, but the good endures."

Musonius Rufus was Epictetus's teacher. Exiled by Nero, he continued teaching philosophy wherever fate sent him.

On moderation:

"We should eat to live, not live to eat."

— Musonius Rufus

posts.text:
"There is only one way to happiness and that is to cease worrying about things which are beyond the power of our will."

— Epictetus

"Don't explain your philosophy. Embody it."

Epictetus was born a slave. His teachings survive through his student Arrian, who recorded the Discourses.

The Stoic perspective on difficulty:

"It's not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters."

— Epictetus

days.imagePrompt: A Roman statesman writing by candlelight, with an hourglass spilling sand and scattered distractions around him, captured in a detailed Renaissance-inspired drawing, 4k

posts.text:
"Sometimes even to live is an act of courage."

— Seneca

"True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future."

Seneca served as advisor to Emperor Nero. His Letters to Lucilius remain among the most accessible introductions to Stoic thought.

On time and its uses:

"It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it."

— Seneca, On the Shortness of Life

posts.text:
"You have power over your mind — not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength."

— Marcus Aurelius, Meditations

"The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts."

Marcus Aurelius never intended the Meditations for publication. These private reflections, written during military campaigns, became one of philosophy's most enduring works.

A morning practice from the Roman Emperor:

"When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive — to breathe, to think, to enjoy, to love."
